data.title: Tight Wallets, Heavy Promotions Pressure Papa John's Results
data.description:
Papa John’s International, Inc. (NASDAQ:PZZA) stock fell Thursday after the pizza chain posted quarterly results that fell short on sales and signaled continued pressure in its North America business.

Investors focused on softer domestic demand and heavier promotions, even as international markets extended their run of growth.

Quarterly Metrics

The company reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings per share of 34 cents, in line with the Street view. Quarterly sales of $498.179 million (down 6% year over year) missed the Street view of $515.002 million.

Global systemwide restaurant sales were $1.23 billion, down 1% from the prior-year fourth quarter.

The company said the decline was mainly driven by a $24 million drop at domestic company-owned restaurants, including about $9 million in lower revenue tied to the refranchising of 85 locations now run by franchisees.

North America comparable sales fell 5%, with domestic company-owned restaurants down 6% and franchised restaurants down 5%.

International comparable sales rose 6% versus the prior-year quarter.

“In the fourth quarter, solid execution drove the company’s fifth consecutive quarter of positive comparable sales in our International markets, while North America results reflected a weak consumer backdrop and elevated promotional environment,” said CEO Todd Penegor.

Papa John’s said it has opened 142 new restaurants systemwide, comprised of 41 restaurant openings in North America and 101 restaurant openings in International markets.

As of December 28, 2025, there were 6,083 Papa Johns restaurants operating in 50 countries and territories.

Quarterly adjusted EBITDA was $51 million compared with $58 million in the prior year quarter. The decrease was primarily attributable to higher expenses related to “incremental investment in marketing and promotional campaigns” in the quarter.

Papa John’s exited the quarter with cash and equivalents worth $36.950 million.

Outlook

Papa John’s expects global systemwide restaurant sales in 2026 to be flat to down low single digits, with North America comparable sales projected to decline 2% to 4% and international comparable sales expected to rise 2% to 4%.

The company plans 40 to 50 gross openings in North America and 180 to 220 internationally.

Operational efficiency initiatives, including recently launched programs, are expected to generate at least $25 million in corporate cost savings outside marketing through 2027. About $13 million of those savings are projected to be realized in 2026.

PZZA Price Action: Papa John’s International shares were down 4.70% at $32.24 at the time of publication on Thursday, according to Benzinga Pro data.

data.title: Nvidia Slumps Over 4%, Wall Street's Fear Gauge Rallies: What's Moving Markets Thursday?
data.description:
Tech stocks tumbled Thursday as investors sold the news following blockbuster results from Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA), dragging the broader semiconductor space lower despite upbeat guidance from the world's largest company.

Each of the Magnificent 7 names traded lower, wiping out roughly $400 billion in market capitalization.

By midday in New York:

  • The S&P 500 was down 0.9%
  • The Nasdaq 100 fell 1.6%
  • Dow Jones slipped 0.3% and
  • The Russell 2000 lost 0.5%.

The CBOE Volatility (VIX) index — also known as the market’s fear gauge — rallied over 10%, on pace for its best session in two weeks.

Sector performance was mixed. Energy outperformed, rising 0.8%, while technology led declines with a 2% drop. Financials added 0.4%, while materials fell 0.8%.

In commodities, gold was up 0.3% to $5,180 per ounce, while silver fell 2.8% to $86 an ounce. Crude oil rose 1.3% to $66.5 a barrel.

In crypto markets, Bitcoin (CRYPTO: BTC) slumped 1.9% to $66,775, partly reversing Wednesday’s 6% gain.

data.title: Nasdaq Stress Gauge Just Hit 2022 Levels — Is A Short-Term Bottom Brewing?
data.description:
Options traders are suddenly betting against the very stocks that have been powering the market higher. Hedging activity across the Nasdaq has surged to levels not seen since the last bear market bottom, signaling a sharp shift in sentiment around key leaders like Nvidia Corp(NASDAQ:NVDA), Microsoft Corp (NASDAQ:MSFT), and Apple Inc(NASDAQ:AAPL).

Extreme Hedging Hits Nasdaq Leaders

The Nasdaq-100's put-to-call ratio has climbed to 1.2, its highest level since the 2022 bear-market low, noted The Kobeissi Letter in an X post:

Outside of that capitulation phase, this marks one of the most aggressive spikes in defensive positioning in over a decade.

This kind of shift typically emerges when uncertainty begins to rise beneath the surface.

Broader Market Hedging Is Rising Too

The signal isn't limited to tech. The S&P 500's put-to-call ratio has climbed to 0.9, its highest level since April 2025 — a period that coincided with a sharp but temporary volatility spike.

Fear Spikes Often Appear Near Turning Points

Historically, extreme hedging tends to cluster near inflection points. The 2022 market bottom formed amid peak put demand, while similar spikes in 2024 and 2025 aligned with short-term corrections that eventually stabilized.

That puts market leaders like Nvidia, Microsoft, and Apple at a critical moment.

The options market isn't predicting the outcome.

But it is signaling that investors are preparing for a move.

data.title: Goldman Sachs Stays Bullish On Nvidia Stock, Sees Nearly 30% Upside (UPDATED)
data.description:
Editor’s Note: This article has been updated to include a video report on the topic.

Goldman Sachs just doubled down on Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA) after a blowout quarter, saying the AI chip giant now has a "clearer path" to outperform in the coming months.

In a note shared Thursday, Goldman Sachs analyst James Schneider reiterated his Buy rating on Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA) and kept his 12-month price target at $250.

That target implies close to 30% upside from current levels.

A Strong Quarter For Nvidia, Even Against High Expectations

Nvidia reported fourth-quarter revenue of $68.1 billion, topping both Goldman's $67.3 billion estimate and Street consensus of $66.2 billion.

Operating EPS of $1.76 also came in well ahead of expectations. Data Center revenue — the key driver of Nvidia's AI-fueled growth — reached $62.3 billion, beating both Goldman and consensus estimates.

Gross margin held firm at 75.2%, while operating margin came in at 67.7%, both essentially in line with forecasts.

The standout: first-quarter guidance.

Nvidia projected revenue of $78 billion at the midpoint, significantly above Street expectations of $72.1 billion. Gross margin guidance of 75% also edged past consensus.

“We see Nvidia accelerating its growth profile in 2026 while maintaining a competitive edge in the market,” Schneider said.

Can Hyperscalers’ AI Spending Keep Climbing?

Schneider said investor expectations were elevated heading into the print, especially after hyperscalers revised capital expenditures higher.

Still, he believes first-quarter guidance exceeded those bullish assumptions.

Goldman outlined three key drivers it believes could push Nvidia shares higher in the coming months:

Nvidia also announced an expanded partnership with Meta Platforms Inc. (NASDAQ:META), which will deploy Blackwell and Rubin GPUs and collaborate on future-generation AI infrastructure.

What’s Next For Nvidia Stock?

"We expect the stock to trade higher following a strong quarter and guidance relative to the Street, and relative bullish expectations heading into the quarter," Schneider said.

Goldman raised its EPS estimates by roughly 2% on higher revenue assumptions and maintained its $250 12-month price target, based on a 30x multiple applied to normalized EPS of $8.25 — implying near-30% upside from current levels.

data.title: Alpha Buying: When Insider Conviction Meets High Yield
data.description:
Insider buying has long been one of the more quietly powerful signals in equity markets. On its own, it offers insight into management conviction. Combined with elevated dividend yields, it can become an especially compelling hunting ground for income-focused investors searching for mispriced assets.

Not every insider purchase leads to outperformance. But when meaningful insider accumulation overlaps with high cash payouts, it often signals that management believes the market has become excessively pessimistic.

At its core, insider buying occurs when executives, directors, or large beneficial owners purchase shares in the open market. These individuals typically have deeper operational visibility and a clearer understanding of forward cash flow trends than outside investors.

High dividend yields, meanwhile, frequently emerge when:

  • Share prices decline sharply
  • Investors question payout sustainability
  • Sentiment turns negative on the sector

That overlap creates a crucial question:

Are insiders buying because the dividend is safer than the market believes — or are they attempting to stabilize sentiment in a deteriorating business?

Why High-Yield Insider Buying Matters

High-yield equities tend to cluster in asset-heavy sectors such as:

  • Real estate investment trusts (REITs)
  • Business development companies (BDCs)
  • Energy infrastructure partnerships
  • Regional and community banks

These industries rely heavily on tangible assets and recurring cash flows. Dividend policy is central to valuation.

When insiders buy aggressively in these sectors, it can signal confidence in:

  • Asset values
  • Credit quality
  • Refinancing opportunities
  • Occupancy trends
  • Lending spreads
  • Hedging structures

Historically, many deep-value income opportunities have begun during periods of negative headlines — when executives stepped in as outside investors stepped away.

Insider buying tends to matter more in high-yield names than in growth stocks because income investors are highly sensitive to dividend cuts. A stock yielding 8% or 10% is typically priced for trouble. Even modest uncertainty around earnings coverage can create severe volatility.

When executives commit personal capital under those conditions, it often suggests they believe the distribution is durable.

The Research Backdrop

Academic studies have consistently shown that clusters of insider purchases tend to outperform over time — particularly when:

  • Multiple executives buy simultaneously
  • Purchases occur near multi-year price lows
  • The company is smaller capitalization
  • Valuation depends heavily on balance sheet interpretation

For income investors, this dynamic can produce a dual benefit:

  1. Sustained yield
  2. Capital appreciation as sentiment recovers

However, insider buying must never be evaluated in isolation.

High yields can signal real financial stress. Insiders are not immune to misjudgment. Investors must examine:

  • Dividend coverage ratios
  • Debt maturity schedules
  • Interest rate sensitivity
  • Refinancing risk
  • Liquidity trends

In leveraged structures such as mortgage REITs or closed-end funds, spreads and financing costs can shift quickly — even when insiders appear confident.

Context and scale matter. A token purchase can be symbolic. Large open-market transactions relative to executive compensation or ownership levels carry more weight. Repeated buying over several quarters strengthens the signal further.

Constructing a High-Yield Insider Portfolio

Building around this strategy requires diversification and discipline.

Income investors benefit from blending exposure across:

  • REITs
  • Infrastructure assets
  • Community banks
  • Energy partnerships
  • Select cyclical income plays

Credit conditions also play a major role. When credit spreads widen, high-yield equities often face pressure even if underlying fundamentals remain stable. These stress periods frequently coincide with increased insider buying — creating opportunity for patient investors.

Insider buying in high-dividend stocks is not a final decision tool. It is a starting point — a lens into management conviction when sentiment has deteriorated.

The objective is not to chase yield, but to identify sustainable distributions supported by:

  • Asset values
  • Conservative leverage
  • Aligned leadership

When insiders are buying alongside shareholders, it often suggests that patience and income discipline may be rewarded.

Current High-Yield Insider Setups

American Assets Trust (NYSE:AAT)

A West Coast-focused REIT with exposure to office and mixed-use real estate, American Assets Trust currently yields approximately 7.3%, supported by an annual dividend near $1.36 per share.

Recent insider accumulation followed a sharp drawdown in commercial real estate sentiment. With shares trading near book value and offering a yield meaningfully above the broader REIT universe, management appears to believe the market is undervaluing the stability of the portfolio's cash flow and asset base during a period of elevated interest rates and CRE uncertainty.

This fits the classic deep-value income framework: durable real assets priced for pessimism.

Prudential Financial (NYSE:PRU)

Prudential offers a different income profile as a global insurer and asset manager generating steady cash flow from retirement and investment businesses.

The stock yields roughly 5.6%, supported by a $5.60 annual dividend that remains covered by earnings and operating cash flow.

Recent director-level insider buying reinforces the idea that management sees value after volatility driven by interest rate swings and capital market uncertainty. Insider accumulation in capital-intensive financial firms often signals confidence in long-term investment spreads and balance sheet resilience — particularly when shares trade below historical valuation multiples.

Enterprise Products Partners (NYSE:EPD)

Enterprise Products Partners remains one of the most stable income vehicles in the midstream MLP space.

With a yield around 6.25%, EPD combines fee-based infrastructure assets with meaningful insider ownership. Recent insider purchases add conviction as distributable cash flow continues to expand and pipeline connections drive volume growth.

For yield-focused investors, insider buying at EPD reinforces the thesis that fee-based energy infrastructure can deliver durable income even when commodity headlines dominate broader sentiment.

Oxford Industries (NYSE:OXM)

Oxford Industries represents a more cyclical high-yield opportunity.

Following a steep share price decline, OXM now yields approximately 7.9%. Insider purchases suggest leadership sees value despite concerns around consumer discretionary demand and earnings volatility.

Unlike the REIT and infrastructure names above, this is not a pure asset-heavy balance sheet story. The yield partly reflects skepticism about growth durability and dividend sustainability.

For income-oriented portfolios, the opportunity lies in potential multiple expansion if fundamentals stabilize — with elevated yield compensating investors during the recovery phase.

The Alpha Buying Takeaway

High-yield insider buying is not about chasing distressed payouts.

It is about identifying moments when management conviction diverges meaningfully from market sentiment.

When:

  • Cash flow coverage remains intact
  • Assets retain intrinsic value
  • Leadership commits personal capital

…there is often an opportunity for disciplined income investors willing to tolerate volatility.

The market frequently overreacts to uncertainty. Insiders sometimes act before sentiment turns.

That divergence is where Alpha Buying lives.
